Graphical abstract A 3D nanoporous pH-stable In-MOF, IITKGP-53, is developed for highly efficient catalyzing largely unexplored solvent-free Strecker reaction. The molecular level understanding of the reaction mechanism and biologically important natural product synthesis employing any nanoporous MOF catalyst is reported herein for the first time. A 3D nanoporous pH-stable In-MOF, IITKGP-53, is developed for highly efficient catalyzing largely unexplored solvent-free Strecker reaction. The molecular level understanding of the reaction mechanism and biologically important natural product synthesis employing any nanoporous MOF catalyst is reported herein for the first time. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are promising candidates as nanoporous heterogeneous catalysts over other solid catalysts. Herein, utilizing a new tetra-acid ligand and employing high-valent Indium metal source we have strategically developed a 3D robust nanoporous framework, IITKGP-53, which retained its crystallinity over a wide range of pH solutions (2–12). Considering the green synthesis approach IITKGP-53 was explored as a heterogeneous catalyst toward one-pot three-component Strecker reaction under solvent-free condition, with low catalyst loading for a broad range of substrates. Considering practical utility, biologically important natural product, Girgensohnine, was synthesized for the first time by using this catalyst with excellent conversion rate. The substrate binding sites inside the nanopores and host–guest interactions were verified crystallographically by obtaining a substrate inside nanopores of this MOF (aniline@IITKGP-53) and computational modeling. An in-depth theoretical investigation unveiled the most plausible transition states for the first time. This study inaugurates the usage of nanoporous MOFs as heterogeneous catalysts for natural product synthesis. Keywords Girgensohnine Heterogeneous catalysis Nanoporous MOF pH-stable Solvent-free Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Natural products have proven to be rich sources of medically- and industrially-important bioactive molecules. Synthesis of natural products is not only challenging but of significant interest. α-aminonitriles are the precursors of amino acids and important building blocks for the synthesis of natural products as well as organic synthesis intermediates [1]. Strecker reaction is one of the crucial and oldest condensation reactions for the synthesis of α-aminonitriles, which offers an atom economy approach [1]. Most importantly, benztriazoles, diamines, and dithanes could also be synthesized by taking advantage of stable iminium ions and using α-aminonitriles. Although several organocatalysts, [2] homogeneous Lewis acid catalysts, [3] and ionic liquids [4] were used to catalyze Strecker reaction, their homogeneous nature, tedious purification processes, and high waste generation make their usage limited [1,4,5]. In this regard, heterogeneous catalysts are promising candidates over homogeneous catalysts having several superiorities such as reduced waste formation, efficient recyclability, and excellent adaptability to continuous flow processes [4–6]. However, nanoporous heterogeneous catalysts are more beneficial than non-porous materials as framework porosity can offer more favorable interaction sites for the substrates and reagents. Hence, having well-defined nanoporosity [7–25] with high surface area [8,11,26–38] and tunable nanoporous structure [39–68] Metal-organic Frameworks (MOFs) are recognized as promising nanoporous heterogeneous catalysts over other solid catalysts, however, surprisingly employment of group 13 elements (In, Ga, Al) based nanoporous MOFs in heterogeneous catalysis are very rare [69]. It should be noted that indium is much less toxic than other nanoporous metal-based MOF catalysts, which makes In-MOF catalysis greener and environmentally benign. In addition, several impactful features of indium such as versatile coordination numbers, good thermal stability, facile Lewis acidic sites offering ability, high-level p-orbitals accessibility of the In3+ cation and the unique electronic configuration beneficial for varying binding affinities to a myriad of coordinated atoms keep nanoporous In-MOFs one hand upper than other transition metal-based MOFs [69]. Taking these superior qualities nanoporous In-MOFs have been explored in several catalysis reactions such as C − C couplings, condensation, and oxidation reactions, although the number is significantly less than other transition metal-based nanoporous MOF catalysts [69]. Most importantly, three-component Strecker reaction catalyzed by nanoporous In-MOF is largely unexplored, in fact restricted to three only [1,70,71]. These three previous reports for nanoporous In-MOFs on catalyzing three-component Strecker reaction do have quite a few pitfalls out of which the most prominent ones are: usage of solvents (halogenated as well), lack of molecular-level understanding in realizing the catalysis pathway by extensive SC-XRD analysis with substrate binding sites inside nanopores and unvaing catalytic transition states by molecular simulations, without any focus on chemical robustness and no attempts for natural product synthesis. In order to obtain the maximum yield, employment of organic solvent is quite common, however, it makes the overall process environmentally harmful. Most importantly, halogens containing volatile organic solvents are more dangerous as they have adverse effects on the ozone layer in the atmosphere and also a significant impact on human health [5,72]. Three-component Strecker reactions catalyzed by all sorts of homo and heterogeneous catalysts are of no exception in terms of usage of such solvents. Thus, the effective design and development of efficient nanoporous In-MOF catalysts for this targeted catalysis reaction under solvent-free condition are worthy. On the other hand, the chemical stability of the developed catalyst is also a prime concern as poor chemical stability often leads to a lower selectivity and poor recyclability. Therefore, the development of highly chemically-stable nanoporous MOFs (preferably pH-stable) along with efficient active sites that could serve the purpose of heterogeneous catalysts with high efficiency is desirable. According to the HSAB principle, a combination of thermodynamic aspects i.e. employment of hard acids (metals with higher oxidation states) and hard bases (ligands having carboxyl functionality) along with consideration of kinetic aspects (employment of hydrophobic benzene moiety and metal center high connectivity) indeed a facile approach for the construction of pH-stable nanoporous MOFs [18]. Besides the exploration of catalytic activity, the molecular level understanding of the reaction mechanism with the insights of possible transition states and formed intermediates along with a clear visualization of the substrate binding sites inside the nanopore cavity could facilitate the progress further. Although Strecker reaction is one of the oldest condensation reactions and a huge number of catalysts (both homo- and heterogeneous) were employed for potentiality assessment, unfortunately, the molecular level understanding of the reaction mechanism by comprehensive theoretical study coupled with SC-XRD structural analysis of the substrate binding sites inside nanopores is still missing in the literature. Although the expected intermediates could be identified from the proposed mechanisms, realization of the transition states remained a daunting task for multi-component catalysis reactions. An in-depth simulation study with enormous number of structural optimizations correlated with energy profile diagram could serve the purpose, which has not yet been explored for multi-component Strecker reaction. In this contribution, besides the exploration of superior catalytic activity by a novel 3D nanoporous In-MOF, IITKGP-53, we aimed to understand the mechanistic pathways thoroughly. To the best of our knowledge such type of in-depth mechanism understanding at the molecular level combinedly with SC-XRD structural analysis and comprehensive theoretical study has not been performed before. Employing a new tetra-acid ligand and high-valent metal source Indium (III), we have constructed a 3D nanoporous In-MOF, IITKGP-53, which exhibited superior framework robustness over a wide range aqueous pH solutions (2–12). IITKGP-53 was employed as MOF-based nanoporous heterogeneous catalyst in one-pot three-component Strecker reaction for the synthesis of α-aminonitriles and a good to excellent yield was observed even for the ketone substrates. Although nanoporous MOFs are widely recognized as promising platforms for multipurpose heterogeneous catalysis, employment of nanoporous MOFs as catalysts for synthesizing natural products remains unexplored till now. Considering such a research gap and to prove the practical utility of our developed catalyst, IITKGP-53 was utilized for the synthesis of Girgensohnine natural product via Strecker reaction by using piperidine in which a high conversion rate (85 %) was achieved. In fact this study reports the first ever natural product synthesis by employing nanoporous MOF as a catalyst. Above all, aniline substrate binding sites inside the MOF nanopores could be observed via SC-XRD structural analysis of aniline-immersed IITKGP-53. To elucidate the host–guest interactions involved for all the substrates along with the product and to understand the reaction mechanism at the molecular level in-depth theoretical investigations were performed. All the intermediates and transition states involved in the catalytic cycle are identified and correlated with the energy profile diagram, which has not been realized before. The excellent pH-stability, superior catalytic activity with lower catalyst loading, excellent recyclability, and scope for the synthesis of natural products made nanoporous IITKGP-53 highly promising as a MOF-based nanoporous heterogeneous catalyst. 2 Results and discussion The solvothermal synthesis of new H4L acid ligand and Indium(III) nitrate metal salt afforded yellowish pellet-type single crystals of IITKGP-53 (Scheme 1 ). Single-crystal structural analysis implies that the new acid ligand-based nanoporous In-MOF, IITKGP-53, crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system having the space group P21/n ( Table S1 , SM). The asymmetric unit contains one Indium metal center and the full unit of the H4L acid ligand having one protonated and three deprotonated carboxylic acid groups ( Figure S4 , SM), which leads the molecular formula of {[In(HL)]·DMF·2H2O} n . The detailed structural analysis reveals that each In(III) metal center is eight coordinated with four different acid units, which are coordinated in bidentate mode and constructed In(CO2)4 SBUs, as displayed in Fig. 1 a. The three benzene rings of H4L acid ligand are flanked in three different directions, which after coordination with the In-metal center constructed an extended 3D nanoporous structure. Interestingly, two types of nanopores were constructed along the crystallographic a-axis in the 3D packing diagram with the channel dimensions of 8.6 × 12.1 Å2 and 4.4 × 6.8 Å2 while considering van der Waals radii (Fig. 1 b). It should be noted that the bigger nanopore was constructed with the help of three In(III) metal centers connected with four different acid units, whereas the smaller one was constructed with the association of two In-metal centers connected with two different acid units. From the topological perspective, In(CO2)4 SBUs and H4L ligands can be regarded as 4 and 3-connected nodes, so the framework structure of IITKGP-53 can be simplified as 4,3-connected three-dimensional (3D) net (Fig. 1 c). The dihedral angle between the planes passing through the single carboxylic acid group-containing benzene rings is 62.5° ( Figure S5 a, SM), whereas the dihedral angles between the planes passing through one carboxylic acid group-containing benzene rings and two carboxylic acid group-containing benzene rings are 88.4° and 72.6°, respectively, as displayed in Figure S5 b, c (SM). The bond distances and bond angles around the metal centers in nanoporous IITKGP-53 are tabulated in Table S2 (SM) and are in the normal range. The well-agreement in the PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized sample with the simulated patterns obtained from the single-crystal data indicates the phase purity of the as-synthesized sample (Fig. 1 d). Easy scalability and high chemical stability are two major concerns of any developed nanoporous framework in terms of practical applicability. Interestingly, overnight refluxing method with the reactants in the same solvent medium afforded good quality single crystals of nanoporous IITKGP-53, whereas normal solvothermal synthesis requires a time of three days (see Experimental section, SM). The indistinguishable PXRD patterns of the bulk-scale sample and the as-synthesized one confirm the phase purity of the bulk synthesized sample (Fig. 1 d). The moisture stability was verified by keeping the as-synthesized sample in a container having 98 % RH for three days. The unchanged PXRD patterns prove good moisture stability of nanoporous IITKGP-53. The water-stability and aqueous medium pH stability were verified by immersing the as-synthesized sample in the respective solutions. The excellent retention of PXRD patterns after 7 days of water immersion along with 24 h immersion of acidic (pH = 2) and basic (pH = 12) solutions confirm the superior chemical stability of the developed nanoporous framework (Fig. 1 d). Such a high chemical stability could be attributed to the combined effect of higher connectivity of the metal center (In3+ metal center is eight-coordinated, a kinetic aspect) and the hard-hard interaction (according to HSAB principle, a thermodynamic aspect) between the high valent In-metal center (hard acid) and oxygen atoms of the carboxylic acid groups (hard bases) [18]. In addition, the enriched hydrophobic benzene rings (another kinetic aspect) of the employed acid ligand provided extra support for the nanoporous framework robustness. To generate the nanopores free framework, the as-synthesized sample was exchanged with low-boiling solvent (dry CHCl3) for three days and activated at 70 °C for 10 h. The good agreement in PXRD patterns for the solvent-exchanged and activated sample (IITKGP-53a, a = activated) confirms the retention of structural integrity even after activation (Fig. 1 e). TGA analysis of the as-synthesized sample displays an initial wt. loss of 5.7 % (calc. 5.6 %) below 100 °C attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules and after that 12.9 % wt. loss was observed below 160 °C (calc. 11.4 %), which could be due to the loss of DMF solvent molecules occupied the nanopores, whereas TGA curve of the activated sample exhibits the successful removal of the nanopore-occupied guest molecules ( Figure S6 a, SM). It may be noted that the gradual weight loss of the activated sample could be attributed to the removal of surface adsorbed water molecules during the quick transfer process of activated sample from an inert sealed tube to the TGA crucible. PLATON analysis reveals 70 % total potential solvent accessible volume of 3463.4 Å3 per unit cell volume (4945 Å3), which are fully occupied by DMF and water solvent molecules. The FT-IR spectra for free linker (H4L) and the as-synthesized MOF (IITKGP-53) were recorded at room temperature in which the COO− symmetric vibration for H4L tetracarboxylic acid shifts to a lower wavenumber from 1684 to 1590 cm−1 for IITKGP-53 and confirms that the carboxylic acid groups are involved in the coordination of the indium metal ( Figure S6 b, SM). Moreover, the absence of a characteristic peak at around 2480 cm−1 in the MOF sample rules out the possibility of the presence of cationic Me2NH2 + species, which is in well-agreement with the crystallographic analysis and molecular formula establishment from the PLATON analysis. Both the IR and elemental analysis of the as-synthesized framework confirm that IITKGP-53 possesses a neutral framework. BET surface area analysis through 77 K N2 sorption was performed with the activated sample to prove the nano-porosity of the developed framework and the BET surface area was obtained to be 192 m2 g−1 ( Figure S7 , SM). The easy scalability, moderate nano-porosity and superior framework robustness prompted us for the exploration of largely unexplored nanoporous In-MOF based three-component Strecker reaction under solvent-free condition. It should be noted that In (III) center in this MOF does not have any OMS to be created after removal of solvents, however, it does have only 8 coordination. It is known that In(III) can have a wide range of coordination numbers in its metal complexes. Thus, even without having any OMS, it can still act as Lewis acidic site for catalytic reactions. Eventually, it is evident both from crystallography and simulation results that the substrates aniline and benzaldehyde are attached to the In(III) centers mostly via electrostatic interactions as detailed in subsequent section. The catalytic performance of IITKGP-53a was analyzed with aniline, trimethylsilylcyanide (TMSCN) and various aldehyde/ketone for the one-pot synthesis of α-aminonitriles. To optimize the catalyst loading and reaction time, the one-pot model reaction was set up under solvent-free condition at room temperature with 1 mol% of IITKGP-53a catalyst loading in presence of benzaldehyde, aniline, and trimethylsilylcyanide ( Table S3 , SM). The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC (thin-layer chromatography) analysis using hexane and ethyl acetate mixture. As displayed in Figure S8 (SM), the catalyst loading and reaction time were varied to obtain maximum yield while keeping all the substrates concentration and reaction conditions unaltered. Interestingly, 0.25 mol% of IITKGP-53a catalyst loading is good enough to lead > 99 % conversion of desired α-aminonitrile product in 25 min (entries 1–10, Table S3 , SM), as displayed in Figure S8-S9 (SM). However, very low product conversion was obtained in the presence of as-synthesized IITKGP-53 (without activation), which signifies that catalysis reaction occurs inside the nanopore cavity and the nanopores need to be vacant (entry 11, Table S3 , SM). Additionally, almost negligible product conversion while using each of the MOF components (In(NO3)3·xH2O, employed tetra-acid ligand), and without the use of a catalyst signifies the effectivity of activated framework toward this direction (entries 12–14, Table S3 , SM). The excellent conversion rate with very low catalyst loading inspired us to explore the catalytic activity of nanoporous IITKGP-53a for various aldehyde/ketone substrates including electron-withdrawing, electron-donating, and bulkier substituents ( Figure S10-S19 , SM). As tabulated in Table 1 , good-to-excellent yields were obtained for each case, which highlights the effectivity of the employed nanoporous MOF catalyst. As the presence of electron-withdrawing groups in the employed substrates favors the nucleophilic attack of the aldehydes/ketones in this targeted catalysis reaction, a relatively higher yield was observed for electron-withdrawing aldehyde/ketone derivatives (entries 3–4, 8–9, Table 1) over their electron-donating counterparts (entries 2, 10, Table 1). Interestingly, a relatively lower yield was observed for the bulkier substrates (entries 5–6, Table 1), which could be attributed to the lesser availability of the framework’s active nanopore sites due to the bulkiness of the substrates. The molecular sizes of 1-Naphthaldehyde (6.7 × 6.1 Å2) and 9-Anthracenecarboxaldehyde (9.1 × 6.2 Å2) are relatively larger than other employed substrates (Table 1). Although, these molecules can easily diffuse through the larger pore of IITKGP-53 (8.6 × 12.1 Å2), the smaller pore 4.4 × 6.8 Å2 may not be accessible. This in turn results in lesser yield for these substrates (89 % and 82 % for 1-Naphthaldehyde and 9-Anthracenecarboxaldehyde, respectively). As expected, the maximum yield (>99 %) was achieved for the smallest substrate benzaldehyde (5.9 × 4.2 Å2) that can have access to both the pores. It should be noted that due to having lesser electrophilicity of ketone than aldehyde the generation of α-aminonitriles from ketones is quite challenging as the activation of ketones is more difficult. There are very few reports on heterogeneous catalyst based Strecker synthesis employing ketones substrates, and the number is significantly less while considering solvent-free reaction pathway [5]. Most importantly, achieving the high yield for ketone substrates in a sustainable manner is very challenging and demanding as they often require usage of high catalyst loading, toxic organic solvents, and higher temperature. IITKGP-53a having well-defined nanopores exhibits high catalytic efficiency for various ketone substrates (entries 7–10, Table 1) despite having lower catalyst loading and solvent-free condition at room temperature, which keeps our developed nanoporous MOF catalyst one hand upper over other catalysts. As mentioned earlier, the number of developed nanoporous MOFs employed in solvent-free one-pot three-component Strecker reaction is significantly less [5] and the reports are even rare while considering In-MOFs, thus a detailed performance comparison may not be meaningful. However, it has been observed that, in all such cases either the catalyst loading or the conversion time was higher than nanoporous IITKGP-53a. This analysis highlights the effectivity of IITKGP-53a as a superior heterogeneous catalyst for this targeted catalysis reaction. As stated before, although a very limited number of nanoporous MOFs were employed in solvent-free one-pot three-component Strecker reaction thus far, no attention had been paid to synthesize any kind of natural product. In fact, so far there are no reports on any kind of natural product synthesis by employing nanoporous MOF catalysts as indicated before. Considering this broad research gap, we have synthesized a piperidine moiety-based natural product, Girgensohnine, employing our developed nanoporous IITKGP-53a catalyst (Scheme 2 ). Girgensohnine is a cyanogenic metabolite extracted with a yield of not more than 0.05 % from the Girgensohnia oppositiflora (Amaranthaceae) shrub. Hence, the strategic design and development of efficient catalyst to obtain a higher yield of Girgensohnine is on-demand. Considering this we have employed our developed IITKGP-53a catalyst for the synthesis of targeted natural product in which an excellent conversion rate (85 %) was observed under the same optimized condition, as characterized by NMR and HRMS ( Figure S20-S21 , SM). To validate the heterogeneous nature of developed IITKGP-53a catalyst, a hot filtration test was performed in which the activated catalyst was removed after 5 min and the reaction was continued for another 20 min under the same conditions. As displayed in Figure S22 (SM), no remarkable progress in product formation after removing the catalyst proved the necessity and effectivity of IITKGP-53a. The recyclability performance was analyzed by consecutive runs of five cycles in which no significant potentiality loss was observed ( Figure S23 , SM). The plausible catalytic cycle of one-pot three-component Strecker reaction for the synthesis of α-aminonitrile is presented in Figure S24 (SM). The facile activation of the carbonyl group from aldehyde/ketone was catalyzed by Lewis acid catalyst nanoporous IITKGP-53a, which was in turn combined with amine group of aniline substrate and generated iminium intermediate [5]. The iminium intermediate was further attacked by CN− from the cyanide source of TMSCN to give the corresponding α-aminonitrile. To gain more insight into the host–guest interactions (framework and substrates interaction inside the nanopores) in the catalytic pathway, we immersed the single-crystals of IITKGP-53 in all the substrates viz. aniline, benzaldehyde/acetophenone and TMSCN. The SC-XRD structural analysis of aniline substrate immersed IITKGP-53 exhibits that aniline molecules are residing inside the nanopore cavity (Fig. 2 ). Aniline incorporated framework (Aniline@IITKGP-53) crystallizes in monoclinic crystal system having the space group Pn ( Table S1 , SM). The guest aniline moieties were stabilized through H-bonding interactions between the hydrogens of the aniline moieties (H3A, H4B) and the oxygen (O2, O16) of the carboxylic units with the H-bond distance of 2.60 and 2.32 Å, respectively (Fig. 2). Unfortunately, several attempts to obtain the single crystals trapped with benzaldehyde/acetophenone or TMSCN or the desired α-aminonitrile product inside the nanoporous framework were not successful due to the sub-optimal data quality. However, such type of in-depth structural visualization is indeed necessary to establish the proposed mechanism, which is still lacking in the literature. Hence, a comprehensive computational study was performed to get a clear molecular insight and to have a better understanding of host–guest binding interactions along with reaction mechanisms. Computational Insights: First-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations are carried out in order to explore binding pockets within In-MOF for different reactants and product involved in the Strecker synthesis. Additionally, a plausible reaction mechanism leading to the product formation is proposed by explicitly analyzing the energy-profile diagram for various transformation steps involved. 2.1 Interactions of the reactants and product with IITKGP-53 To explore and identify preferred binding sites for the reactants (PhCHO, PhNH2, and TMSCN) and product molecules involved in the Strecker synthesis interacting with the In-MOF, all the reactants and product were loaded into the MOF and then relaxed to the minimum energy structure starting from multiple initial geometry guesses using periodic DFT as implemented in VASP (see SM computational section for details). Here, it is worth mentioning that during structural relaxation IITKGP-53 and PhNH2 geometries were frozen at their respective crystallographic positions. Relative binding stability of individual components with the IITKGP-53 is quantified by calculating binding energy ( E b ). The optimized geometries of reactants and product loaded into In-MOF together with calculated E b and van der Waals (vdW) contributionre shown in Fig. 3 and Figure S25 (SM), respectively. Calculated E b for the PhCHO is −29.8 kcal mol−1 with vdW contribution of −10.9 kcal mol−1. A closer look at the optimized complex structure reveals PhCHO residing very close to the In (III) centre with the O of the –CHO group is 4.22 Å from the In(III) centre, resulting in strong electrostatic stabilizing interaction. In addition, –CHO oxygen is in close proximity (ca. ∼ 1.51 Å ) to the hydrogen of one –COOH group, causing strong H-bonding interaction. For PhNH2, calculated E b of –22.6 kcal mol−1 with a vdW contribution of −12.6 kcal mol−1 clearly indicate the importance of both electrostatic and non-covalent interactions almost equally governing the binding stability. Interaction of electron-rich N of the –NH2 group with the In(III) at 4.53 Å distance provides modest electrostatic stabilization. In addition, –NH2 group also participated in hydrogen bonding interaction with –COO- group situated at a distance of 2.17 Å . On the other hand, TMSCN is weakly bound to the In-MOF as compared to other two reactants. The stabilization as quantified by E b of −12.1 kcal mol−1 is mainly guided by weak non-covalent vdW interaction rather than any strong electrostatic interaction. In fact, the major contribution to E b stems from the non-covalent vdW interaction ( E v d W = -8.6 kcal mol−1). To determine the fate of the product formed (specifically the binding site and stability) we have also modeled the interaction of the product molecule inside the nanoporous In-MOF (see SM Figure S25 for the optimized structure). Calculated E b of −28.6 kcal mol−1 clearly suggests product stability within the MOF structure, which is majorly guided by the non-covalent vdW interaction (ca. E v d W ∼ –22.8 kcal mol−1). 2.2 Energy profile diagram of IITKGP-53 catalyzed Strecker synthesis The plausible mechanism of the In-MOF catalyzed Strecker synthesis is proposed and analyzed in detail using DFT. The overall reaction can be visualized consisting of the following three reaction steps and for each step involved, the Gibbs free energy change ( Δ G) and activation barrier were calculated at 298.15 K temperature and 1.0 atm pressure (Fig. 4 , see SM for computational details). Step 1: Formation of Ph-HC(OH)–NH-Ph (R→I1): The reaction proceeds through the nucleophilic attack of lone pairs of aniline N to the carbonyl C of benzaldehyde, leading to C-N bond formation. The carbonyl C gets activated by the In(III) situated at 4.47 Å well consistent with earlier reports [70,71]. This is followed by a proton transfer from N to O to neutralize the positively charged N and negatively charged O. As a result, first intermediate (I1) Ph-HC(OH)–NH-Ph is formed [73]. The I1 is found to be 3.6 kcal mol−1 more stable than the interacting reactants (R) within the MOF. As depicted in Fig. 4 , I1 formation proceeds through the first transition state (TS1) that is identified to be the proton residing in between O and N center at a distance of 1.34 Å and 1.22 Å , respectively and is 30.5 kcal mol−1 higher in energy than R. Here it is worth mentioning that the H-bonding interaction between carboxylate O of the MOF and the hopping proton stabilizes the TS1 state. Step 2: Formation of Ph-HC=N-Ph (I1→I2) via dehydration: In this step, an imine formation occurs via dehydration (i.e., removal of a H2O molecule). Ph-HC=N-Ph is the second intermediate (I2) formed [1]. Calculations suggested I1 to I2 transformation as an endothermic process, but I2 is 1.8 kcal mol−1 more stable than the R. I2 formation proceeds through TS2 that is 52.9 kcal mol−1 higher in energy than R. This step is identified to possess the highest activation energy barrier (ca. ∼ 56.5 kcal mol−1) and hence the rate-determining step. At I1 geometry, the distance of carbonyl O and a second H of aniline N is ∼ 2.80 Å , which is quite large for realizing the dehydration. The N-C bonds are proposed to rotate in the I1 structure forming TS2, so that H is attached to N and the OH attached to the C reside in the same plane. After dehydration an imine (I2) is formed and an in-situ H2O molecule is released, which plays a crucial role in the subsequent step as discussed below. Here it is important to note that the H-bonding interaction between –OH group H and O of carboxylate group of the In-MOF facilitates the dehydration process. Step 3: Formation of the product i.e., Ph-HC(CN)–NH-Ph (I2→P): This step occurs via multiple concerted processes. Firstly, in-situ H2O residing near to the imine N at ∼ 1.97 Å distance displays a H-bonding interaction. At this configuration, O of the in-situ H2O causes electrostatic interaction with the Si of TMSCN at ∼ 2.77 Å distance. This favorable interaction of Si and O of the H2O molecule facilitates CN– release as well as heterolytic H2O splitting into H+ and OH–. The CN– thus released gets stabilized through the anion- π interaction with the phenyl group of the In-MOF. During this process, H+ gets attached to imine N and pulls electron density toward it and thereby generating partial positive charge at the C center. Subsequently, released CN– then attacks to the partially positively charged C and eventually forms the product (P) molecule. Here importantly, we note that the TMSOH formation from TMSCN occurs via inversion of the methyl groups from one side to other side through an almost planar TS3 geometry. In fact, a planar TMS cationic structure is identified to be the TS3, simultaneously interacting with CN– and –OH of H2O. This transformation is associated with an activation energy of ∼ 53.0 kcal mol−1. Finally, the product (P) formed is ∼ 24.1 kcal mol−1 more stable than the initial R, making the entire chemical transformation thermodynamically favorable and indeed the process is exothermic in nature. 3 Conclusion In summary, employing a new tetra-acid ligand, we have constructed a 3D highly robust nanoporous In-MOF, IITKGP-53, potential for one-pot three component Strecker reaction under solvent-free condition. The superior catalytic performances were explored with more challenging ketone derivatives and the catalyst could be easily recovered and readily recycled. Considering the research gap in natural product synthesis employing nanoporous MOF, Girgensohnine natural product was synthesized in which an excellent conversion was achieved. Most importantly, aniline substrate binding sites inside the nanopores were identified by SC-XRD analysis and an in-depth computational study was performed to visualize the preferential binding interactions of all the substrates and the desired α-aminonitrile product. Moreover, the energy profile diagram for different intermediates and transition states is evident in the reaction pathway. It should be noted that such kind of in-depth study at the molecular level has not been performed previously. This study inaugurates a new avenue for the synthesis of natural products by using nanoporous MOF catalysts. Such a detailed insight into the nature of the interactions involved among the substrates within the nanopores of framework with in-depth understanding in chemistry of catalytic phenomena at the molecular level will surely be appealing to the researchers in further design of the nanoporous catalysts with better activities in near future. coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are promising candidates as nanoporous heterogeneous catalysts over other solid catalysts. Herein, utilizing a new tetra-acid ligand and employing high-valent Indium metal source we have strategically developed a 3D robust nanoporous framework, IITKGP-53, which retained its crystallinity over a wide range of pH solutions (2–12). Considering the green synthesis approach IITKGP-53 was explored as a heterogeneous catalyst toward one-pot three-component Strecker reaction under solvent-free condition, with low catalyst loading for a broad range of substrates. Considering practical utility, biologically important natural product, Girgensohnine, was synthesized for the first time by using this catalyst with excellent conversion rate. The substrate binding sites inside the nanopores and host–guest interactions were verified crystallographically by obtaining a substrate inside nanopores of this MOF (aniline@IITKGP-53) and computational modeling. An in-depth theoretical investigation unveiled the most plausible transition states for the first time. This study inaugurates the usage of nanoporous MOFs as heterogeneous catalysts for natural product synthesis.
